rules.title: Suspicious Office Process Spawning Encoded Shell
rules.description: Detects Microsoft Word spawning command shells with encoded commands, indicative of phishing payload execution
falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros executing PowerShell/CMD with encoded commands
Administrative scripts using Office applications to launch shells

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Activity with Obfuscation
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution with indicators of malicious commands or obfuscation such as encoded commands and long strings.
falsepositives: Legitimate PowerShell scripts using administrative tasks
DevOps tools using encoded commands for deployment

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Windows Service Creation or Modification
rules.description: Detects potential persistence through Windows service creation or modification using service control utilities
falsepositives: Legitimate software installation/updates
System administration tasks
Endpoint protection services

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Potential Process Injection via Suspicious Parent-Child Process Relationship
rules.description: Detects potential process injection through known injector processes spawning command interpreters with suspicious command line arguments
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded commands
Application development/debugging activities

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell CommandLine Indicators for Application Layer C2
rules.description: Detects PowerShell command lines with patterns associated with Application Layer Protocol command and control activity
falsepositives: Legitimate PowerShell scripts using web requests for administration
Developer tools using curl/wget for downloads
Systems using encoded commands for configuration management

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Command Interpreter Execution Patterns
rules.description: Detects command interpreter execution with suspicious arguments or parent processes associated with phishing documents
falsepositives: Legitimate PowerShell scripts using encoded commands for administration
Office macros spawning shells in trusted documents

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation with Obfuscation Indicators
rules.description: Detects processes associated with command-line obfuscation techniques such as encoded commands or hidden window execution.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of encoded commands in administrative scripts or developer tools.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Potential C2 Channel Exfiltration Using CLI Tools
rules.description: Detects potential data exfiltration over command and control channels using common command-line utilities with suspicious parameters
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts using these utilities for file transfers
Web development workflows using curl for HTTP testing
Certificate management operations using certutil

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application via Suspicious Process Execution
rules.description: Detects potential exploitation of public-facing applications via suspicious child processes and encoded command patterns originating from web servers or archiving tools
falsepositives: Legitimate web application administration tasks
Archive software performing automated extraction workflows
System administrators using encoded commands for scripting

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Potential OS Credential Dumping via Suspicious Process Execution
rules.description: Detects processes and command lines associated with credential dumping techniques including LSASS access, registry hive exports, and Mimikatz-style patterns.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of tasklist.exe for process monitoring
Registry backup operations using reg.exe
Security tools performing authorized credential audits

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Network Service Discovery via Command-Line Tools
rules.description: Detects execution of common network service discovery utilities (netstat, nmap, PowerShell network cmdlets) launched from a command shell, indicating ATT&CK technique T1046.

detection.condition: (selection_netstat or selection_nmap or selection_ps) and parent_cmd

falsepositives: Legitimate administrators running netstat or nmap for troubleshooting
Scheduled scripts that use PowerShell network cmdlets for inventory
Security tools that perform regular network scans

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Archive Collected Data
rules.description: Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious Scheduled Task Creation via Unusual Parent Process
rules.description: Detects scheduled task creation from unusual parent processes with suspicious command line patterns associated with persistence mechanisms.

detection.condition: selection and not filter and (selection2 or selection3 or selection4)

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts
Backup software using scheduled tasks
Package managers creating maintenance jobs

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detects Input Capture via Keylogging Scripts
rules.description: Detects potential input capture activity via PowerShell or Windows Script Host executing keylogging-related commands or encoded scripts.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using .NET APIs
Use of encoded commands in administrative tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Screen Capture Activity Detection
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity through known utilities or .NET screen capture methods
falsepositives: Legitimate use of screenshot utilities
Administrative scripts using screen capture for documentation

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: User Execution of Potentially Malicious File via Suspicious Parent or Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects execution of scripting interpreters (PowerShell, cmd.exe, wscript.exe) where the parent process is a known archive extractor or the command line contains encoded or obfuscated patterns, indicating possible user execution of a malicious file.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell -EncodedCommand for deployment
Enterprise automation tools that invoke PowerShell or cmd.exe with encoded arguments
Users extracting archives that contain legitimate scripts which are executed automatically

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.description: Basic phishing test by creating a file with a suspicious message
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named phishing_test.txt in the temporary directory with a test message

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Test'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing test by displaying a popup form
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a popup window with the title 'Phishing Test'

attacks.description: Advanced phishing test by decoding a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the contents of phishing_test.txt into a new file named phishing_test_decoded.txt in the temporary directory

attacks.command: echo 'Please enter your password: ' > phishing_test.txt; cat phishing_test.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing attempt by creating a file that prompts the user to enter their password.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named phishing_test.txt with content that could trick a user into entering their password, demonstrating a basic phishing attempt.

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing attempt using zenity to create a GUI prompt for user credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses zenity to create a graphical prompt that asks the user to enter their credentials, simulating a more sophisticated phishing attempt.

attacks.command: xterm -e 'echo Please enter your sensitive information: ; read'
attacks.description: Advanced phishing attempt by opening a new terminal window and prompting the user to enter sensitive information.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens a new terminal window and prompts the user to enter sensitive information, demonstrating an advanced phishing technique.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command to get the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes PowerShell and prints the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command to create a file with test content
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the TEMP directory with the content 'Test content'

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command to encode a command and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes the 'Get-Date' command using Base64 and saves it to a file named encoded.txt in the TEMP directory

attacks.description: Basic command to get the current date and time
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current date and time

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello World!'

attacks.description: Advanced command to compress a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a zip file named test.zip in the temporary directory containing the test.txt file

attacks.description: Create a new system process using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system process will be created

attacks.description: Start the newly created system process using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The system process will be started

attacks.description: Create a new system process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system process will be created

attacks.description: Start the SSH daemon to create a new system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon will start, creating a new system process

attacks.description: Restart the SSH daemon to modify an existing system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon will restart, modifying the existing system process

attacks.description: Create a new cron job to create a system process at regular intervals
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be created, running the SSH command at regular intervals and creating a system process

attacks.description: Basic process injection using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd process will be started and will print 'Hello World!' to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd process will be started and will print 'Hello World!' to the console.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell with .NET classes (NOT RECOMMENDED)
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd process will be started and will print 'Hello World!' to the console. Note: This command is not recommended as it uses .NET classes directly.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using bash shell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a temporary file with a malicious payload and then execute it using the bash shell.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using bash shell with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file with a malicious payload in the /etc directory and then execute it using the bash shell. This requires elevated privileges and poses a higher safety risk.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using bash shell with background execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a temporary file with a malicious payload in the /dev/shm directory and then execute it using the bash shell in the background. This demonstrates a more advanced process injection technique.

attacks.description: Basic: Establishes a simple PowerShell connection to test C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a benign PowerShell command to test connectivity.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Uses certutil to download a file from a URL and then displays its contents, simulating a C2 server communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL and displays its contents, demonstrating C2 communication.

attacks.description: Advanced: Utilizes PowerShell's Invoke-WebRequest to download a file from a URL and then displays its contents, showcasing a more complex C2 communication scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL using PowerShell and displays its contents, demonstrating advanced C2 communication capabilities.

attacks.description: Establish a basic network connection to a server using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: A network connection is established to the specified server on port 80.

attacks.description: Send a POST request with test data to a server using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: A POST request is sent to the specified server with the test data.

attacks.description: Use ssh to execute a command on a remote server, writing to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test_file.txt is created on the remote server with the content 'Test command'.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using cmd.exe to create a text file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to display a message box.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the text 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.description: Advanced command using PowerShell to write to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes 'Hello from PowerShell' to the console.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a simple bash script that writes 'Hello World' to a file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in /tmp containing the text 'Hello World'.

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo $i > /tmp/number_$i.txt; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate command that executes a bash script to create five files in /tmp, each containing a number from 1 to 5.
attacks.expected_behavior: Five files named number_1.txt to number_5.txt will be created in /tmp, each containing a corresponding number.

attacks.command: bash -c '(echo "#!/bin/bash"; echo "echo Advanced Script Executed") > /tmp/advanced_script.sh; chmod +x /tmp/advanced_script.sh; /tmp/advanced_script.sh'
attacks.description: Advanced command that creates a bash script in /tmp, makes it executable, and then executes it, demonstrating more complex scripting capabilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script named advanced_script.sh will be created in /tmp, made executable, and then executed, printing 'Advanced Script Executed' to the console.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test string' > $env:TEMP\test.txt; certutil -encode $env:TEMP\test.txt $env:TEMP\encoded.txt
attacks.description: Creates a test file, encodes it using certutil, and saves the encoded version as a new file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates two files in the temp directory: the original test file and its encoded version.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a file with a simple string, demonstrating how information can be obfuscated in a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named obfuscated.txt in the temp directory with the string 'Hello World' and then displays its contents.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo This is another test > $env:TEMP\hidden.txt && attrib +H $env:TEMP\hidden.txt"
attacks.description: Creates a hidden file in the temp directory, demonstrating file obfuscation by hiding it from normal directory listings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden file named hidden.txt in the temp directory. The file will not be visible in a standard dir command listing unless the /A parameter is used.

attacks.description: Creates a file with obfuscated content using base64 encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's home directory with the decoded string 'Hello world!'

attacks.description: Obfuscates a file using AES encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts the file test.txt in the user's home directory using AES-256-CBC and saves it as test.enc

attacks.description: Obfuscates a file by converting it to a hexadecimal representation
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.hex in the user's home directory with the hexadecimal representation of the original file

attacks.description: Simulate exfiltration by uploading a test string to a hypothetical C2 server using PowerShell's WebClient.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to upload a test string to a specified URL, simulating data exfiltration over a C2 channel.

attacks.description: Create a test file, then use Invoke-WebRequest to post its contents to a hypothetical C2 server, demonstrating exfiltration of local data.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file is created in the temp directory with test data, and then its contents are posted to a specified URL, simulating the exfiltration of local data.

attacks.description: Use certutil to download a file from a URL to the temp directory, then display its contents, simulating the reception and handling of data from a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file is downloaded from the specified URL to the temp directory, and its contents are displayed in the console, simulating the reception and handling of commands or data from a C2 server.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using netcat to send the passwd file to the attacker's IP on port 4444
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the contents of /etc/passwd to the attacker's system, demonstrating data exfiltration over a C2 channel.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration using curl to POST the shadow file to an attacker's URL
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uploads the contents of /etc/shadow to the specified URL, simulating exfiltration of sensitive data.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration involving archiving sensitive files and sending them over netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The command archives /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow, then sends the archive to the attacker's IP on port 4444, demonstrating a more complex exfiltration scenario.

attacks.description: Exploiting a public-facing application by downloading and executing a malicious payload using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL and executes it, simulating an exploit.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to download an exploit from a public-facing application and execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an exploit and executes it, demonstrating a potential attack vector.

attacks.description: Basic command to test file creation and reading capabilities, simulating initial access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file and displays its contents, verifying basic system functionality.

attacks.description: Basic exploit using curl to send a GET request with a malicious parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: The curl command sends a GET request to the vulnerable web application, exploiting the vulnerability

attacks.description: Intermediate exploit using wget to download and execute a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The wget command downloads the malicious script and pipes it to bash for execution, exploiting the vulnerability

attacks.description: Advanced exploit using python to create a simple HTTP server and curl to send a GET request to the malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The python command creates a simple HTTP server, and the curl command sends a GET request to the malicious script, exploiting the vulnerability

attacks.description: List all user accounts on the system, potentially revealing usernames or credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: List stored credentials for network resources.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials for network resources.

attacks.description: Interact with the Windows Credential Manager using PowerShell. This command initializes a SecureString object, which can be used to handle credentials securely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Initializes a SecureString object in PowerShell, potentially for further credential handling.

attacks.description: Retrieve user information, potentially dumping credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user information, including potential credential data

attacks.description: Search for password entries in system files
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files containing 'password', simulating credential dumping

attacks.description: Combine shadow and password files to dump credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named 'credentials.txt' containing combined user and password data

attacks.description: View all active connections and listening ports to discover network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all active connections and listening ports, which can be used to identify available network services.

attacks.description: Query network services by name using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists services related to network functions, helping in the discovery of network services.

attacks.description: List all started services, which can include network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all started services, allowing for the identification of running network services.

attacks.description: Display all active Internet connections, routing tables, and interface statistics
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of all active Internet connections, routing tables, and interface statistics.

attacks.description: Display socket statistics
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of socket statistics.

attacks.description: Perform a TCP connect scan on the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will perform a TCP connect scan on the local machine and display a list of open ports.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving a collected data file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a test file in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate example that first creates a file with test data and then archives it, simulating the collection and archiving of sensitive data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file with test data and then archives it, demonstrating data collection and archiving.

attacks.description: Advanced example that creates a directory for collected data, adds a file to it, and then archives the entire directory, simulating a more complex data collection and archiving scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory, adds a file to it, and then archives the directory, demonstrating a more advanced data collection and archiving process.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving collected data using 'tar'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified data without altering the original files.

attacks.description: Intermediate example that changes the directory before archiving, ensuring the archive is created with the correct structure.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the data in the specified directory, maintaining the directory structure.

attacks.description: Advanced example using 'find' to select files and 'tar' with '--null' option to archive files based on the 'find' output, handling file names with special characters safely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of files found by 'find', handling file names safely and avoiding potential issues with special characters.

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task named 'TestTask' that writes 'Test' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and executed daily, writing to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Create a weekly scheduled task named 'IntermediateTask' that uses PowerShell to append 'Intermediate Test' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and executed weekly, appending to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Create a monthly scheduled task named 'AdvancedTask' that writes 'Advanced Test' to a file in the temp directory and then waits for 10 seconds.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and executed monthly, writing to a file and then pausing for 10 seconds.

attacks.description: Backup existing cron jobs to a file in the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named cron_backup.txt will be created in the user's home directory containing the current cron jobs.

attacks.command: (crontab -l ; echo "0 0 * * * echo 'Test cron job executed' >> $HOME/cron_test.log") | crontab -
attacks.description: Append a new cron job that runs daily at midnight, writing a test message to a log file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be scheduled to run daily at midnight, appending 'Test cron job executed' to $HOME/cron_test.log

attacks.description: Backup existing cron jobs for the root user to a file in the current user's home directory, requiring admin privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named root_cron_backup.txt will be created in the user's home directory containing the current cron jobs for the root user.

attacks.description: Simulate keystroke input using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulated keystrokes are sent to the active window

attacks.description: Open Notepad and simulate input using SendKeys
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens and receives simulated input

attacks.description: Use WScript Shell to simulate keystroke input
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulated keystrokes are sent to the active window

attacks.description: Monitor and record keyboard and mouse events using xinput
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will start monitoring and recording keyboard and mouse events

attacks.description: Simulate keyboard input using xdotool
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will simulate pressing the 'a' key

attacks.description: Capture input using script command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the input 'Test string'

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -MemberDefinition '[DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr GetDesktopWindow();' -Name U32 -Namespace W; $hwnd = [W.U32]::GetDesktopWindow(); $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:TEMP\screenshot.png");"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save it as a PNG file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file named 'screenshot.png' in the user's temp directory.

attacks.description: Use mspaint to capture the screen and save it as a PNG file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command opens mspaint, captures the screen with a resolution of 1920x1080, and saves it as 'screen_capture.png' in the temp directory.

attacks.description: An advanced screen capture using PowerShell, specifying the capture area and saving it as a PNG.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command captures a specified area of the screen (1920x1080 starting from the top-left corner) and saves it as 'advanced_screenshot.png' in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Capture the screen and save it as an image file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the current screen and save it as a PNG image file in the /tmp directory.

attacks.description: Record the screen and save it as a video file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record the screen at 25 frames per second and save it as an MP4 video file in the /tmp directory.

attacks.description: Record the screen using the libx264 codec and save it as a video file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record the screen at 25 frames per second using the libx264 codec and save it as an MP4 video file in the /tmp directory.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a malicious file using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be executed if it exists in the current directory or the system's PATH.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution using PowerShell to start a malicious file from the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be executed from the temp directory if it exists.

attacks.description: Advanced execution involving downloading and executing a malicious file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be downloaded to the temp directory and then executed if the operation is successful.

attacks.description: Creates a malicious file, gives it execution permissions, and then executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named 'malicious_file.sh', makes it executable, and then runs it. The 'Malicious payload' should be replaced with a benign string for testing purposes to avoid actual harm.

attacks.description: Downloads a potentially malicious file, makes it executable, and then executes it. Note: This command assumes internet access which might not be available in all test scenarios.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL, changes its permissions to executable, and then executes it. This command poses a higher risk as it involves downloading content from the internet, which could potentially be malicious.

attacks.description: Creates a Python file with malicious content and then executes it using the Python interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a Python file in the user's home directory, and then runs it. The 'Malicious payload' should be a benign Python script for testing purposes.
